title:
Comparison between disintegrated and fermented sewage sludge for production of a
carbon source suitable for biological nutrient removal
abstract:
There is a need to investigate processes that enable sludge re-use while
enhancing sewage treatment efficiency. Mechanically disintegrated thickened
surplus activated sludge (SAS) and fermented primary sludge were compared for
their capacity to produce a carbon source suitable for BNR by completing
nutrient removal predictive tests. Mechanically disintegration of SAS using a
deflaker enhanced volatile fatty acids (VFAs) content from 92 to 374 mg l−1
(4.1-fold increase). In comparison, primary sludge fermentation increased the
VFAs content from 3.5 g l−1 to a final concentration of 8.7 g l−1 (2.5-fold
increase). The carbon source obtained from disintegration and fermentation
treatments improved phosphate (PO4-P) release and denitrification by up to 0.04
mg NO3-N g−1 VSS min−1 and 0.031 mg PO4-P g−1 VSS min−1, respectively, in
comparison to acetate (0.023 mg NO3-N g−1 VSS min−1and 0.010 mg PO4-P g−1 VSS
min−1). Overall, both types of sludge were suitable for BNR but disintegrated
SAS displayed lower carbon to nutrient ratios of 8 for SCOD:PO4-P and 9 for
SCOD:NO3-N. On the other hand, SAS increased the concentration of PO4-P in the
settled sewage by a further 0.97 g PO4-P kg−1 SCOD indicating its potential
negative impact towards nutrient recy

Title: Comparison between disintegrated and fermented
sewage sludge for production of a carbon source suitable for
biological nutrient removal
Authors: Ana Soares, Pantelis Kampas, Sarah Maillard,
Elizabeth Wood, Jon Brigg, Martin Tillotson, Simon A.
Parsons, Elise Cartmell

Comparison between disintegrated and fermented sewage sludge for production 1 
of a carbon source suitable for biological nutrient removal  2

a.soares@cranfield.ac.uk (A. Soares) 10

Abstract 12 
There is a need to investigate processes that enable sludge re-use whilst enhancing sewage 13 
treatment efficiency. Mechanically disintegrated thickened surplus activated sludge (SAS) and 14 
fermented primary sludge were compared for their capacity to produce a carbon source suitable for 15 
BNR by completing nutrient removal predictive tests. Mechanically disintegration of SAS using a 16 
deflaker enhanced volatile fatty acids (VFAs) content from 92 to 374 mg l
-1
 (4.1 fold increase). In 17 
comparison, primary sludge fermentation increased the VFAs content from 3.5 g l
-1
 to a final 18 
concentration of 8.7 g l
-1
 (2.5 fold increase). The carbon source obtained from disintegration and 19 
fermentation treatments improved phosphate (PO4-P) release and denitrification by up to 0.04 mg 20 
NO3-N g
-1
 VSS min
-1 
and 0.031 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS min
-1
, respectively, in comparison to acetate 21 
(0.023 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS min
-1
and 0.010 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS min
-1
). Overall, both types of sludge 22 
were suitable for BNR but disintegrated SAS displayed lower carbon to nutrient ratios of 8 for 23 
SCOD:PO4-P and 9 for SCOD:NO3-N. On the other hand, SAS increased the concentration of PO4-24

P in the settled sewage by a further 0.97 g PO4-P kg
-1
 SCOD indicating its potential negative impact 1 
towards nutrient recycling in the BNR process. 2 
Keywords: denitrification; mechanical disintegration; phosphorus release; primary sludge; surplus 3 
activated sludge 4 
 5 
1. Introduction 6 
Removal of phosphorus (P) and nitrogen (N) from wastewater effluents is important to ensure 7 
environmental protection of surface waters. High concentrations of nutrients in rivers have been 8 
related to eutrophication [1]. Biological nutrient removal (BNR) processes are widely used to 9 
remove nutrients from wastewater, however for the phosphate accumulating organisms (PAO) and 10 
heterotrophic denitrifiers to be able uptake P and reduce nitrate (NO
-
3) respectively, the wastewater 11 
must have sufficient carbon to favour their metabolism [2]. It has been reported that 6-10 mg of 12 
volatile fatty acids (VFAs) or 20 mg chemical oxygen demand (COD) as acetic acid are required to 13 
remove 1 mg of phosphorus [2] and that 3-4 mg COD as acetic acid per 1 mg  of total nitrogen are 14 
required for denitrification [3]. More recently, a study in a sequencing batch biofilm reactor 15 
demonstrated that 7 mg l
-1
 of acetate are required to remove 1 mg P l
-1
 [4]. To achieve the essential 16 
carbon to nutrient ratio, the wastewater can be supplemented with an industrial effluent rich in 17 
soluble carbon or chemicals such as ethanol, methanol or acetate to the wastewater. However, the 18 
dependence of BNR over the existence of local industries or the costs associated with transport and 19 
chemical storage facilities can be significant, decreasing the attractiveness of these external carbon 20 
sources. Alternatively, a carbon source rich in VFAs, which are the most suitable carbon source for 21 
BNR [5], can be produced at the sewage treatment works (STWs) by disintegration or fermentation 22 
of sewage sludge. This approach can stimulate sludge re-use as an alternative to anaerobic digestion 23 
and potentially improve BNR efficiency [6].  24 
 25 
Page 3 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
3 
Nevertheless, the question remains as to what sludge source to use and the appropriate mechanism 1 
to apply for VFAs production. Fermentation of primary sludge can promote VFAs production [7, 8] 2 
and this method is currently used in countries such as South Africa and the USA for internal carbon 3 
source production for BNR [9]. The sludge retention time in the fermenter is critical to achieve high 4 
VFAs production in order to enhance hydrolysis and acidogenesis without methane gas formation. 5 
Hence, the sludge retention time must be lower than 6 to 10 days depending on the temperature 6 
20°C to 10°C, respectively [10, 11]. Fermentation of secondary sludge has been described to be 7 
complex due to the composition of the sludge, mainly microbial cells and flocs, which are difficult 8 
to breakdown under anaerobic conditions [12-14]. Furthermore, VFAs-COD equivalent production 9 
from SAS fermentation has been reported to be low with 21 mg g
-1
 volatile suspended solids (VSS) 10 
compared with primary sludge fermentation 226 mg g
-1
 VSS [15]. Alternatively the production of 11 
an internal carbon source from secondary sludge can be achieved through mechanical 12 
disintegration. This has been demonstrated to increase the soluble chemical oxygen demand 13 
(SCOD) and VFAs content by disrupting microbial flocs and cells using pressure and friction forces 14 
[16, 17]. However, there is little information about the application of the disintegrated sludge to 15 
BNR in order to improve P and N removal [18] and how it compares with primary sludge 16 
fermentation. 17 
 18 
The aim of this study was to compare fermented primary sludge and disintegrated SAS, both 19 
centrifuged supernatant and disintegrated sludge, for producing a carbon source suitable for BNR. 20 
The two methods were compared in terms of VFAs production rate, type of VFAs released and 21 
SCOD release rates. Furthermore, the nutrient removal potential of the internal carbon sources was 22 
determined by completing nutrient removal predictive tests and comparing removal rates with 23 
acetate – an external carbon source. The implications of each of the technologies to the overall 24 
treatment process were also assessed in relation to the possible internal recycling of nutrients within 25 
the STW. 26 
Page 4 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
4 
2. Materials and methods  1 
2.1 Mechanical disintegration of surplus activated sludge 2 
Five litres of thickened surplus activated sludge (SAS) was collected from a 1 m
3
 BNR pilot-plant 3 
and mechanically disintegrated using a 10” Pilao DTD Spider Deflaker with a 30 kW motor fitted 4 
with 230 mm discs with 3 active cell layers according to Kampas et al. [16]. The disintegration 5 
process was conducted as a batch. A portion of the disintegrated sludge was centrifuged for 20 min 6 
at 8804 g (Hettich Zentrifugen, Tuttlingen, Germany). The centrifuged supernatant and 7 
disintegrated sludge were used within hours after disintegration for nutrient removal predictive tests 8 
and analysed for VFAs, SCOD, nitrate (NO3-N), ammonium (NH4
+
)  and PO4-P contents.    9 
 10 
2.2 Fermentation of primary sludge  11 
Primary sludge was collected from five full-scale STWs  (Yorkshire, UK) with population 12 
equivalents (PE) of 499,065, 386,123, 373985, 373,985, 573,394 and 18,914 for Sites 1, 2, 3, 4 and 13 
5, respectively. Four and half litres of primary sludge were fermented in 5 l vessels (quickfit flask 14 
100 mm flange bore, height 290 mm QRE-130-B, Fisher, UK) for 4 days at room temperature (20-15 
23°C).  The sludge was mechanically mixed at a constant speed of 0.7 g by overhead motor stirrers 16 
(Heidolph RZR 2020 and 2102, Schwabach, Germany) with anaerobic conditions promoted by 17 
sealing the fermentation vessels. Every 12h, 60 ml of sludge was sampled for VFAs analyses and 18 
every 24h for total suspended solids (TSS), SCOD, pH, NH4
+
 and PO4-P analyses. All 19 
fermentations were completed in duplicate. At the end of 80h, the fermentation product obtained 20 
from the sludge collected at Site 1 was centrifuged for 20 min at 8804 g (Hettich Zentrifugen, 21 
Tuttlingen, Germany) and the supernatant stored frozen at -20°C for nutrient removal predictive 22 
tests. This fermentation product was selected because it displayed high VFAs production from an 23 
initial concentration 2.2 g l
-1
 to a final 6.3 g l
-1
 (2.8 fold increase) and presented typical VFAs 24 
contents of fermented primary sludge with 44% acetic acid and 35% propionic acid [19]. 25 
Page 5 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
5 
2.3 Nutrient removal predictive tests  1 
Phosphorus release and denitrification testes were conducted in 2.5 l plexi-glass vessels at 25°C 2 
according to method described by Kampas et al. [20]. A mixture of 1 l wastewater and 1 l returned 3 
activated sludge (RAS), collected from a full-scale BNR plant in Derbyshire, UK was placed in 4 
each of the five vessels used for the nutrient removal predictive tests. Nitrogen gas was 5 
continuously supplied to the headspace of the vessels to ensure anaerobic conditions. The vessels 6 
were mixed with magnetic stirrers at 20.2 g and the pH and dissolved oxygen continuously 7 
monitored with stable values at 7.2-7.5 and < 0.15 mg l
-1
, respectively. Vessel 1 was used as a 8 
control without a carbon source addition, vessel 2 was spiked with a solution of sodium acetate and 9 
vessels 3, 4 and 5 were spiked with liquor obtained from the fermented primary sludge, 10 
mechanically disintegrated SAS and supernatant from the SAS disintegration, respectively. This 11 
experimental configuration was used for a total of 4 different tests for phosphorus release and 12 
denitrification when the amount of carbon added to each vessel was matched in SCOD (50 mg l
-1
) 13 
and total VFAs (3.5 mg l
-1
) contents (Table 1). 14 
 15 
For the denitrification tests, 20 mg KNO3 l
-1
 was added to each vessel at the beginning of the 16 
experiment to ensure sufficient nitrate in the wastewater. The tests were completed for 2 and 20h 17 
for the phosphorus release and denitrification tests, respectively. Samples of 60 ml were taken every 18 
0.5h for the first 2h. The samples were analysed for VSS, SCOD, PO4-P and NO3-N. Phosphate 19 
release and denitrification rates were calculated after 2h and 1.5h, respectively.  Replicates of the P 20 
release and denitrification tests were not completed because the wastewater and RAS  needed to be 21 
used within 1-2 hours after collection. Therefore the 4 series of experiments were completed in 22 
batches and results compared [20].  23 
 24 
 25 
 26 
Page 6 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
6 
2.4 Analytical methods  1 
The samples were centrifuged at 8804 g for 20 min (Hettich Zentrifugen, Tuttlingen, Germany) 2 
and the supernatant filtered through a 0.45 μm (glass-fiber filter paper) prior to analyses. Chemical 3 
oxygen demand, NO3-N, NH4
+
, PO4-P were determined using Merck Spectroquant cell test 4 
(Darmstadt, Denmark) according to the manufacturer instructions. Solids determination, TSS and 5 
VSS, was performed according to Standard Methods [21]. All the analyses were completed in 6 
duplicate.  7 
 8 
For VFAs determination, 9 ml of the filtrate was placed in 10 ml plastic tubes and acidified with 9 
10 μl of sulphuric acid (98% purity) and frozen until high performance liquid chromatography 10 
(HPLC) analyses was completed. The VFAs samples were analysed in triplicate using a HPLC 11 
(Shimadzu VP Series, Shimadzu, Milton Keynes, UK) with the ultraviolet (UV) detector set at 12 
208 nm. The columns Biorad (cat. 125-0115) (105 mm × 7.8 mm) and the guard column (Biorad 13 
cat. 125-0131) were maintained at 65°C. The injection volume was 15 μl and each sample was run 14 
for 0.5h using 1 mM sulphuric acid pumped at a flow rate of 0.8 ml min
-1
. A mixture of VFAs 15 
(acetic acid, propionic acid, butyric acid and valeric acid analytical grade) at concentrations 16 
between 0.05 - 1 g l
-1
 was used as internal standard.   17 
 18 
3. Results and discussion  19 
3.1 Soluble COD and VFAs production   20 
Soluble COD and VFAs concentrations of SAS increased to 3.6 g l
-1 
and 0.37 g l
-1 
after mechanical 21 
disintegration by a deflaker corresponding to a 9 fold and 4.1 fold increases from initial values, 22 
respectively (Table 2). The primary sludge was fermented during 80h and after this period the 23 
SCOD increased to a maximum value of 10.3 g l
-1
 (Site 5) with an average SCOD increase of 2 fold 24 
for all sources of primary sludge fermented (Table 2). Likewise, the VFAs concentration increased 25 
to an average value of 6.5 g l
-1
 with the highest VFAs production observed for the sludge from Site 26 
Page 7 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
7 
5 with a final concentration of 8.7 g l
-1
. The maximum increase in VFAs was 2.5 fold from the 1 
initial concentration (Table 2).  2 
 3 
 The VFAs and SCOD production yields from SAS disintegration were 6 g VFAs kg
-1
 TSS and 62 g 4 
SCOD kg
 -1
 TSS. In comparison, the yields from primary sludge fermentation were 81 g VFAs kg
-1
 5 
TSS and 95 g SCOD kg
 -1
 TSS. The SCOD and VFAs yields indicate that primary sludge 6 
fermentation promoted VFAs production while SAS disintegration mainly induced SCOD release. 7 
Full-scale static primary sludge fermenter thickeners have yields of 25-40 g VFAs kg
-1
 sludge after 8 
2-3 days [9], which are in the same order of magnitude of the yields described here.  9 
 For all types of sludge fermented (Sites 1 to 5) and disintegrated SAS the production of VFAs was 10 
found to be linearly correlated with SCOD release (Fig. 1).  The correlation factors (R
2
) were 11 
calculated over the 80h fermentation period and the values recorded were between 0.99 (Site 2) and 12 
0.86 (Site 5) and therefore can be considered linearly correlated.  Hence, VFAs were the main 13 
SCOD constituent during fermentation independent of the initial sludge initial characteristics. 14 
Fermentation of sludge is described the happen through hydrolysis of complex organic matter into 15 
soluble organic compounds that are transformed into volatile fatty acids during acidogenesis. 16 
Between 69-94% of the SCOD generated during primary sludge fermentation from sites 1-5 were 17 
VFAs (Table 2, Fig.1). Others have reported a proportion of 85% VFAs [5]. Comparatively, only 18 
approximately 12% of the SCOD released during SAS disintegration were VFAs. In a previous 19 
study it was demonstrated that the SCOD released during SAS disintegration was composed of 20 
proteins (30%), carbohydrates (13%) and VFAs (12%) but the remaining 45% of the SCOD was not 21 
characterised [16]. Other studies have also identified SCOD as the main product  [22]  that could be 22 
fractionated into proteins, extracellular polymeric substances and soluble microbial products  after 23 
ultrasound [23, 24] or thermal treatment [25], but the identification of the complete range of 24 
substances that contribute to SCOD has not yet been described.   25 
 26 
Page 8 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
8 
Mainly acetic acid (41%) and propionic acid (36%) were produced during primary sludge 1 
fermentation for Sites 1, 2 and 3 with an acetic acid production of 47-62 g kg
-1
 TSS (Fig. 2). Other 2 
authors have observed equivalent VFAs production after fermentation of primary sludge at 20°C 3 
with 43% of acetic acid and 41% of propionic acid [19]. VFAs production was observed to 4 
predominantly occur during the first 40h of primary sludge fermentation with rates between 0.118 g 5 
VFAs h
-1
 (Site 1) to 0.188 g VFAs h
-1
 (Site 5). Between 46h and 80h, fermentation processes 6 
occurred at a lower rate and the VFAs formation rates decreased to values of 0.03 g VFAs h
-1
 (Site 7 
1). On the other hand, SAS disintegration mainly produced acetic acid (90%) and propionic acid 8 
(10%) (Fig. 2). 9 
 10 
3.2 Nutrient removal predictive tests  11 
Nutrient predictive tests can be used to estimate the BNR performance using a specific carbon 12 
source [20]. These tests are based on the PO4-P release after a specific period of time and the 13 
denitrification rates, giving an indication of P and N removal, respectively. Two tests were 14 
conducted in order to match the carbon addition in VFAs (3.5 mg l
-1
) and SCOD  (50 mg l
-1
) 15 
concentration with the aim of assessing separately the influence of SCOD and VFAs on P and N 16 
removal. The nutrient removal tests were done in parallel using the same source of wastewater 17 
implying the same microbial community as inoculum and only parameter that was changed was the 18 
carbon source. Therefore it should be possible to compare the impact of the different carbon sources 19 
on the nutrient removal rates.  20 
 21 
When the carbon addition was matched in total VFAs concentration, the highest P release rates 22 
were obtained for the disintegrated SAS supernatant and disintegrated SAS with values of 0.026 23 
and 0.025 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS min
-1
, respectively (Fig. 3a). Comparable results were obtained in the 24 
denitrification tests with the highest denitrification rates measured for the SAS disintegrated sludge 25 
and supernatant 0.039 and 0.036 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS min
-1
, respectively (Fig. 4a).When the carbon 26 
Page 9 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
9 
addition was matched in terms of SCOD the highest phosphorus release rate was obtained for 1 
disintegrated SAS (0.031 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS min
-1
) and the lowest for acetate (0.024 mg PO4-P g
-1
 2 
VSS min
-1
) (Fig. 3a). The denitrification tests showed the same trend with rates of 0.038, 0.040 and 3 
0.039 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS min
-1
 for disintegrated SAS, disintegrated SAS supernatant and fermented 4 
primary sludge, and the lowest rate for acetate with 0.027 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS min
-1
 (Fig. 4a).  5 
From the nutrient predictive tests it can be established that the carbon obtained from the sludge was 6 
more suitable for BNR (phosphate release and denitrification) than the external acetate carbon 7 
source because primary sludge fermentation and disintegrated SAS gave higher phosphate releases 8 
and denitrification rates. This observation is supported by Fig. 3b and 4b that show phosphate 9 
releases and denitrification rates above the values in the control and acetate vessels (baseline). 10 
Furthermore, the denitrifying bacteria seem to be able to use a wider range carbon sources as 11 
identified through the comparison of rates when the carbon was matched in total VFAs and SCOD 12 
(Figure 4b). Denitrification metabolism is favoured over phosphate release because denitrifying 13 
bacteria compete over readily available carbon sources with PAOs and can use wider type of carbon 14 
[26].  The denitrification rates recorded (1.4-1.9 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS h
-1
) were similar to those 15 
obtained with ozonated SAS as a carbon source [29] (Table 3). Denitrification rates have been 16 
demonstrated to be dependent on the biomass concentration [30] but also the origin of the biological 17 
material and its activity [31] which could possibly explain the high rates obtain in other studies that 18 
varied between 7-41 mg NO3-N g
-1
 VSS h
-1
 (Table 3). This emphasizes that denitrification tests 19 
should be completed for a specific wastewater/carbon source and compared with a control using the 20 
same source of denitrifying bacteria [20].  Treatment of ammonia and nitrate in anaerobic 21 
conditions has also been demonstrated by using enriched cultures of ANAMMOX (anaerobic 22 
ammonium oxidation bacteria) [27]. 23 
 24 
 25 
Page 10 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
10 
The phosphorus release rates (0.9-1.5 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS h
-1
) determined for the internal carbon 1 
sources were in the same range of reported rates, between 1.3-2.5 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS h
-1
 (Table 3). 2 
The PAOs responsible for phosphate release, were more selective with regard to carbon source use 3 
as was demonstrated by differences in the PO4-P release rates when the carbon source was matched 4 
in total VFAs in comparison with SCOD (up to 0.01 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS min
-1
 higher when matched 5 
in total VFAs) (Fig. 3b). The internal carbon sources not only contained VFAs, but also other 6 
substances that contributed to the SCOD. The SCOD of the wastewater after internal carbon 7 
addition matched on VFAs was on average 63 mg l
-1
 (fermented primary sludge addition) and 91 8 
mg l
-1 
for the disintegrated SAS in comparison with 50 mg l
-1
 in the vessel supplemented with 9 
acetate. Hence, the microbial species that complete phosphate release not only use VFAs but also 10 
other sources of soluble carbon [20]. Adaptation of the biomass to the carbon source could further 11 
enhance the phosphorus release rates to 5.9 mg PO4-P g
-1
 VSS h
-1
 as it has been demonstrated by 12 
Puig et al. [28].  13 
 14 
3.3 Carbon to nutrient ratios 15 
The fermented primary sludge and the disintegrated sludge were further compared by calculating 16 
the carbon to phosphorus (SCOD:PO4-Prelease) and carbon to nitrate (SCOD: NO3-N) ratios which 17 
can be used to estimate the BNR potential of a specific wastewater/carbon source [2] (Table 3). The 18 
SCOD:PO4-Prelease ratio varied between 8:1 for disintegrated SAS and 15:1 for acetate and the 19 
SCOD:NO3-N ratio ranged between 9:1 and 12:1 (Table 3). Both SCOD:PO4-Prelease and SCOD: 20 
NO3-N ratios indicate that the most effective carbon source for BNR was disintegrated SAS. A 21 
substantial difference between SCOD:PO4-Prelease for disintegrated SAS and fermented primary 22 
sludge with values of 8 and 15, respectively, was observed. As previously described, nutrient 23 
release with disintegrated SAS was not enhanced by the presence of viable PAOs after 24 
disintegration [20]. The difference between SCOD:PO4-Prelease ratio recorded for the SAS and 25 
primary sludge carbon sources was likely to be linked to the type of carbon and bioavailability. The 26 
Page 11 of 26

an

pt
 
 
11 
main SCOD component of fermented primary sludge was VFAs corresponding to 90% of the 1 
SCOD and this type of carbon source has been extensively studied for BNR enhancement [2, 7, 8]. 2 
Yet the SCOD products of SAS disintegration have not been completely identified since only 3 
approximately 12% were VFAs with 45% of the SCOD remaining uncharacterised [16]. Further 4 
work needs to be completed to identify the products of the SAS disintegration that enhance BNR (P 5 
release and NO3
-
 reduction) at rates above acetate and fermented primary sludge (Table 3).  6 
 7 
 3.4 Implications of using primary sludge fermentation and SAS disintegration as carbon sources to 8 
the sewage treatment works 9 
The disintegration of SAS was observed to enhance NH4
+
 and PO4-P concentrations from 10 mg 10 
NH4
+ 
l
-1
 and 159 mg PO4-P l
-1
 to 60 mg NH4
+
 l
-1
and 500 mg PO4-P l
-1
, respectively, i.e. the nutrients 11 
increased by a factor of 6 (NH4
+
) and 3.5 (PO4-P) (Table 2). The SAS disintegration promoted 12 
higher phosphate release than sludge fermentation since this nutrient is removed from the 13 
wastewater by accumulation in the biomass [32] and it was solubilised during the disintegration 14 
process.  The NH4
+
 and PO4-P concentrations were also observed to increase during the 15 
fermentation period (Table 2) and a strong correlation was observed between acetic acid production 16 
with both ammonia (correlation factors R
2
 from 0.73 to 0.96) and phosphorus release (correlation 17 
factors R
2 
from 0.88 to 0.94). On average, the PO4-P and NH4
+
 release from the fermentation of 18 
primary sludge was 2.1 and 4 fold higher than the initial concentration of 18.3 mg PO4-P l
-1
 and 19 
111.9 mg NH4
+
 l
-1
.  20 
The implications of using primary sludge fermentation and SAS disintegration as carbon source 21 
were assessed by completing a nutrient mass balance to a full-scale BNR treatment works treating 22 
10,000 m
3
 day
-1
 of wastewater (Table 4). The volumes of fermented primary sludge and 23 
disintegrated SAS added to the BNR settled sewage were calculated based on predictive tests match 24 
on SCOD (fermented primary sludge 4.2 ml in 2 l of wastewater and disintegrated SAS 13 ml in 2 l 25 
of wastewater) with dilution factors of 0.0021 and 0.0065 in the wastewater, respectively. The 26 
Page 12 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
12 
addition of fermented sludge would increase the ammonia load by 13 kg day
-1
 and PO4-P by 2 kg 1 
day
-1
 in the settled sewage fed to the BNR process. The addition of disintegrated SAS was likely to 2 
increase the PO4-P in the settled sewage feeding the BNR process by an additional load of 33 kg 3 
day
-1
.   4 
 5 
The ratios of nutrient recycled to the BNR versus SCOD feed to the process indicate that the use of 6 
disintegrated SAS as internal carbon source could lead to a cycling of phosphorus in the STW with 7 
0.97 g PO4-P kg
-1
 SCOD. Ammonia concentrations would also be increased (0.11 g NH4
+
 kg
-1
 8 
SCOD) but to a lesser extent than for phosphorus (Table 4). The addition of primary sludge 9 
fermentation products for enhancing the BNR process is recommended since the recycling of 10 
nutrients would be minimised (0.02 g PO4-P kg
-1
 SCOD and 0.13 g NH4
+
 kg
-1
 SCOD). For the SAS 11 
disintegration product to be a suitable carbon source for BNR and complement the beneficial carbon 12 
to nutrient ratios here described, the phosphorus would potentially need to be removed from the 13 
disintegration liquors. Phosphate removal could be achieved using chemical precipitation with iron 14 
sulphate or alum or alternatively, struvite (MgNH4PO4.6H2O)  formation could be promoted by 15 
providing suitable conditions for its precipitation (pH 8.5 and a ratio of 1:1:1 of 16 
phosphate:ammonia: magnesium) with 80% phosphate recovery  [33]. In addition, an economical 17 
evaluation has demonstrated that sludge disintegration using a deflaker is an energy intensive 18 
process (6138 kW day
-1 
in a 50,000 m
3
 day
-1
 treatment works) [20] in comparison with sludge 19 
fermentation with virtually no operational costs associated [9].    20 
 21 
4. Conclusions  22 
The fermentation of primary sludge promotes VFAs production as 69-94% of the SCOD generated 23 
consisted of VFAs, compared with approximately 12% VFAs in the SCOD released during SAS 24 
disintegration. Higher VFAs yields were observed during the first 40h of fermentation.  25 
 26 
Page 13 of 26
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
13 
The nutrient removal tests demonstrated that internal carbon sources obtained from sewage sludge 1 
enhanced phosphate release and denitrification compared with acetate. The disintegrated SAS was 2 
the more suitable carbon source for BNR compared with fermented primary sludge (SCOD:PO4-3 
Prelease ratio of 8 and SCOD:NO3 ratio of 9) since other components contributing to SCOD besides 4 
VFAs promoted BNR. Further work should be completed to identify these products of SAS 5 
disintegration. However for disintegrated SAS to be considered a suitable carbon source for BNR 6 
the PO4-P would potentially need to be removed before recycling to the BNR wastewater. Overall 7 
the addition of primary sludge fermentation products for enhancing the BNR process is 8 
recommended since the recycling of nutrients would be minimised (0.02 g PO4-P kg
-1
 SCOD and 9 
0.13 g NH4
+
 kg
-1
 SCOD).  10
